sen.j: 神郡（しんぐん/かみこおり）とは、国郡制成立に伴い神社の神域（神の領土）として誕生した他郡とは違う特別な郡のことである。
sen.e: A Shingun (also called a Kamiokori) is a special district type that came into existence with the establishment of the Kokugun system, and is considered to be the holly precincts of a shrine (domain of a kami), and differs from other types of districts.

A Shingun (also called a Kamiokori) is a special district type that came into existence with the establishment of the Kokugun system, and is considered to be the holly precincts of a shrine (domain of a kami), and differs from other types of districts.

A Shingun (also called a Kamikori) is a special district type that came into existence with the establishment of the Kokugun system, and is considered to be the holly precincts of a shrine (domain of a kami), and differs from other types of districts.

sen.j: 大化の改新によって国郡制が成立し、649年に神郡制度が成立した。
sen.e: The Kokugun system was established by the Taika Reforms, and the Shingun system was established in the year 649.
The Kokugun system was established by the Taika Reforms, and the Shingun system was established in the year 649.
The Kokugun system was established by the Taika Reforms, and the Shingun system was established in the year 649.

sen.j: 伊勢神郡
sen.e: Ise Shingun
Ise Shingun
Ise Shingun

sen.j: その由来は古く、天日別命の子孫・大若子命が磯部川（ただし実際には下樋小川であるという）以東の土地を天照大神に寄贈した「神国」（後世言われる神国とは無関係）に由来する。
sen.e: The origins of the system are derived from the mythological days of yore when Owakugo-no-mikoto, a descenant of Amenohiwake-no-mikoto bestowed upon Amaterasu Omikami of the lands, "Shinkoku" (no relation to later concepts called "shinkoku") east of the Isobe-gawa River (however, it is said that the river is actually the Shitahi-ogawa River).

The origins of the system are derived from the mythological days of yore when Owakugo-no-mikoto, a descenant of Amenohiwake-no-mikoto bestowed upon Amaterasu Omikami of the lands, "Shinkoku" (no relation to later concepts called "shinkoku") east of the Isobe-gawa River (however, it is said that the river is actually the Shitahi-ogawa River).

The origins of Ise Shingun are derived from the mythological days when Owakugo-no-mikoto, a descenant of Amenohiwake-no-mikoto bestowed upon Amaterasu Omikami of the lands, 'Shinkoku' (no relation to later concepts called 'shinkoku') east of the Isobe-gawa River (however, it is said that the river is actually the Shitahi-ogawa River).
sen.cmt: the system→Ise Shingun" "→' '原文になく、なくても意味が通じるので of yore 削除しました。

sen.j: 神郡成立後は、渡相郡・竹郡に分割され後に度会郡・多気郡と改称した。
sen.e: After the establishment of the Shingun, it was divided into Watarai-no-kori and Take-no-kori, which were subsequently renamed as Watarai-gun (written with different characters for "Watarai") and Taki-gun.

After the establishment of the Shingun, it was divided into Watarai-no-kori and Take-no-kori, which were subsequently renamed as Watarai-gun (written with different characters for "Watarai") and Taki-gun.

After the establishment of the Shingun, it was divided into Watarai-no-kori and Take-no-kori, which were subsequently renamed as Watarai-gun (written with different characters for "Watarai") and Taki-gun.

sen.j: 664年に多気郡から飯野郡を分割して公領とした。
sen.e: In the year 664 Ino-gun was separated from Taki-gun, and made a Koryo (an Imperial demesne).
In the year 664 Ino-gun was separated from Taki-gun, and made a Koryo (an Imperial demesne).
In the year 664 Iino-gun was separated from Taki-gun, and made a Koryo (an Imperial demesne).

sen.j: だが、宇多天皇の889年に同郡を伊勢神宮に1代限りの再寄進を行い、897年に醍醐天皇への譲位が決まると同郡を永遠に神郡に復帰させる事とした。
sen.e: In the year 889, however, Emperor Uda again donated the said gun to the Ise Jingu for a span of one generation only, and when it was decided that Emperor Uda would abdicated and Emperor Daigo aceeded to the throne in 897, the said gun was permanantly returned to the Shingun.

In the year 889, however, Emperor Uda again donated the said gun to the Ise Jingu for a span of one generation only, and when it was decided that Emperor Uda would abdicated and Emperor Daigo aceeded to the throne in 897, the said gun was permanantly returned to the Shingun.

In the year 889, however, Emperor Uda again donated the said gun to the Ise-jingu Shrine for a span of one generation only, and when it was decided that Emperor Uda would abdicated and Emperor Daigo acceded to the throne in 897, the said gun was permanantly returned to the Shingun.

sen.j: このため、この3郡を特に「神三郡（じんさんぐん）」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: That is the reason that the abovementioned three gun, in particular, are called the Jinsangun (three districts of the Jingu).
That is the reason that the abovementioned three gun, in particular, are called the Jinsangun (three districts of the Jingu).
That is the reason that the abovementioned three gun, in particular, are called the 'Jinsangun' (three districts of the Jingun).

sen.j: 後に、神国思想の高まりとともに伊勢国内の諸郡は次々と神郡に編入されていった。
sen.e: Subsequently, accompanying the rise to prominence of the Shinkoku ideology, one gun after another in Ise Province was incorporated into the Shingun.
Subsequently, accompanying the rise to prominence of the Shinkoku ideology, one gun after another in Ise Province was incorporated into the Shingun.
Subsequently, accompanying the rise to prominence of the Shinkoku ideology (thought of Japan as the land of the gods), one gun after another in Ise Province was incorporated into the Shingun.

sen.j: 飯高郡
sen.e: Iitaka-gun
Iitaka-gun
1185: Iitaka-gun

sen.j: 平安時代末期から、有力貴族や他の有力寺社が神郡内に荘園を設定したため、実質的に伊勢神宮の領地が浸食されていった。
sen.e: From the later part of the Heian Period, influential members of the aristocracy and prominent temples and shrines established estates within the precincts of the Ise Jingu, whereby the actual lands in the precincts of the Jingu became encroached upon.

From the later part of the Heian Period, influential members of the aristocracy and prominent temples and shrines established estates within the precincts of the Ise Jingu, whereby the actual lands in the precincts of the Jingu became encroached upon.

From the later part of the Heian Period, influential members of the aristocracy and prominent temples and shrines established shoen (manor in medieval Japan) within the precincts of the Ise-jingu Shrine, whereby the actual lands in the precincts of the Jingu became encroached upon.
sen.cmt: 荘園の定訳伊勢神宮の表記訂正

sen.j: 元寇で「神風」が喧伝されると、鎌倉幕府は「神風」発生の功労として「興行法」と呼ばれる一種の徳政令を公布し、こうした荘園を全て没収して伊勢神宮に与えた。
sen.e: If a "Kamikaze" proclamation was issued because of a Mongol invasion of Japan, to contribute meriutoriously the Kamakura Bakufu would promulgate an Estate Recovery Act, which was a type of Tokuseirei (an order for the return of sold land and the dissolution of debts), whereupon all such estates would be siezed and returned to the Ise Jingu.

If a "Kamikaze" proclamation was issued because of a Mongol invasion of Japan, to contribute meriutoriously the Kamakura Bakufu would promulgate an Estate Recovery Act, which was a type of Tokuseirei (an order for the return of sold land and the dissolution of debts), whereupon all such estates would be siezed and returned to the Ise Jingu.

When a 'Kamikaze' proclamation was issued because of a Mongol invasion of Japan, the Kamakura Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) meritoriously promulgated an 'Estate Recovery Act', which was a type of Tokuseirei (an order for the return of sold land and the dissolution of debts), whereupon all such estates were siezed and returned to the Ise-jingu Shrine.
sen.cmt: " "→' '幕府の説明補足「興行法」に ' 'meriutoriously→meritoriouslyかなり書き換えました。

sen.j: 有名な御家人に対する永仁の徳政令が1年で廃止されたのに対して、こちらは「神罰の発生の恐れ」を盾に廃止されなかった。
sen.e: For renowned gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods), such a Tokuseirei would be abolished after a period of one year; however, as such orders where to function as a shield against the "risk of divine punishment", the order was not abolished for everyone.
sen.cmt: unclear phrase, "盾に廃止されなかった"
sen.e: For renowned gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods), such a Tokuseirei would be abolished after a period of one year; however, as such orders where to function as a shield against the "risk of divine punishment", the order was not abolished for everyone.

The famous Einin no Tokuseirei for gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods) was abolished after a period of one year; however, this order was not abolished as a shield against the 'risk of divine punishment'.
sen.cmt: 永仁の徳政令を訳に加えて、かなり書き換えました。

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府滅亡後は神郡の横領が続き、江戸幕府から「神領」として保障されたのは約6千石であったという。
sen.e: After the fall of the Muromachi Bakufu, the Edo Bakufu continued to guarantee the "Shingun" as a 6,000 koku fiefdom.
After the fall of the Muromachi Bakufu, the Edo Bakufu continued to guarantee the "Shingun" as a 6,000 koku fiefdom.
After the fall of the Kamakura Bakufu, the Shingun was continuously arrogated, and the 'Shingu' the Edo Bakufu guaranteed was only about 6,000 koku fiefdom.
sen.cmt: 訳抜け、誤訳があるので、かなり書き換えました。
